channel.name: papyrology
channel.topic: mostly amateur papyrology, with some world class experts politely tolerating the rest of us

messages.content: **Thursday May 25th at 8am PST** we’ll have a Q&A with part of our Papyrology Team. Let’s use this channel to gather questions for them ahead of time.
Here's one, how do you distinguish between similar looking letters (e.g. Α, Δ or ω,ψ) when they are partially missing/obscured
yeah, i would rephrase as: given the date it was carbonized, what is the expected alphabet/s we could encounter?
Any prominent differences between ancient papyrus and the modern stuff you can buy on Amazon?
How does ink flow on papyrus like this? Are there certain shapes of air pockets in the sheet?
Interesting, I didn't realize some were in Latin script

Here are some questions I have asked our resident papyrologist over the last few months. We've gotten decent answers to many of these, so I'd prioritize other, newer questions mostly, but I would also be curious to hear further discussion on much of this from the expert panel.

* What are the odds the scrolls we are looking at are blank? Is there precedent for finding blank scrolls in the collection?
* What is the expected gap between columns of text? How much does this vary?
* What are the expected margins at the top and bottom of the sheet? How much does this vary?
* Are scrolls typically filled completely with text, or sometimes partially, or what?
* Are scrolls typically wound in a consistent direction? In other words, does the direction of the spiral in our CT images indicate which end is likely the top and which is the bottom?
* Is the text always expected to be axis-aligned with the fiber pattern, i.e. not diagonally?
* Is the text ever written over the overlap where two sheets were hammered together? (I got conclusive photographic evidence that this does in fact happen sometimes in the Herculaneum collection so this is pretty settled)
* What would we expect the join/overlap between sheets (technical/Greek term: kolleseis) to look like in CT?
Great questions here, wow!

Another: it is often difficult for us to tell in CT what is "one sheet" that has delaminated into multiple "layers" and what is truly "multiple sheets." Do you have any recommended clues or guidance for navigating this problem?
How many papyrus layers (alternating horizontal/vertical) can we expect a single sheet of papyrus to have?  Is this known for other herculaneum scrolls?

I am pretty sure the expectation here is two layers, one horizontal and one vertical, of course with four layers in the compressed overlap areas. But like everything else I would feel better about it if I heard this confirmed from the panel, so I'm not trying to answer the question on their behalf 😂

In general, my experience has been that many things vary quite a bit across the collection, since the scrolls represent a period of at least three centuries and many different hands. And the scholars specialize, so they might have different answers to these things. Which is why I'm so excited about getting a bunch of them together in a panel!
Well that makes sense, but back when I modeled the strands of a piece on  fragment 3 I counted 3. HVHVHV. I guess it could be 3 sheets stuck together.
Could be, but I'm with you, it's hard to say!
Maybe we should start a google doc and curate the list in order of importance.
I grabbed the Sider book, been enjoying it.
I was thinking about this, I don't think it's in scope for this project, but it almost breaks down to a beam search/ generative problem

A question: When they first found the library, they did inadvertently destroy a lot of scrolls, but finally, they invented a technique to read some of the scrolls, and even without the advanced technologies we have today, they did manage to read some stuff. Why then is our scroll (the one in the challenge) so hard to read, even with all the technology that we are applying to it? Might there be other scrolls out there that are more readily legible? Did we just scan the hardest ones?
(Not a papyrologist) They could only read the scrolls because they unrolled them (and destroyed most of them in the progress)
If we physically unrolled the two challenge scrolls we'd destroy them, but we would get some fragments with legible text too

The goal of this challenge is to read them using the X-ray scans, since this is non-intrusive, i.e. we don't have to destroy them in the process. They're hard to read because on the X-ray scans the ink  is not visible to the naked eye, but it's thought that machine learning might be able to detect it; hence the ink detection challenge. You can find more on the website https://scrollprize.org

messages.content:
Good stuff.  Points I had wondered about:
The scribe writes on the side where the papyrus strips are horizontal (i.e. a word or sentence runs along a strip).  Thus the inside, written-upon strips are circumferential in the rolled scroll.  The vertical strips, parallel to the axis, are on the outside.  The papyrus tends to roll in this direction.

(I wonder if this is why scrolls of this time were written in this direction, while medieval parchment scrolls were written in the other direction, with the sentences parallel to the axis.)

Non-black inks mentioned tend to have metal, so (pure speculation) if a scribe had decided to e.g. use red for certain things (fancy capitals at the starts of chapters, the words of Caesar) then that would make those letters show up.  Likewise color illustrations.

Two questions, if possible:
- looking at the center image of scroll1, would they say that it was folded? (or at least, was this common then?) If so, where should we expect ink, on the inside / outside or both?
- are illustrations / fancy capitals / decorations common in scrolls from this period of Roman culture?

I (amateur papyrologist) can answer this one: if we can understand what is preceding/following the letter, we can usually infer which it will be. Even more concretely if we know what literary work we're reading (e.g. if we know it's the *Iliad*, we can then 'fill in the blank' with ease).
So I assume if the letters are sparse then it's more or less impossible?
Yeah, it's definitely a significant challenge if they're quite obscured. We have a way of notating that we can see an unknown character.
But it’s this stage considered a “win” for the purpose of the contest? According to the rules have to be perfectly readable. I find this quite hard to achieve
That’s actually a good question both for the professional papyrologist and challenge runners
Human masked language model exercise!

The question was posed to determine how to distinguish between similar letters when the papyrus is heavily damaged. Perfect reading of damaged papyri hasn't yet been achieved even with those that have already been transcribed. I believe your goal is to read ink perfectly, so that a papyrologist can determine what is written to the best of their training.

Q: I've read (but do not really believe) that they didn't use spaces between words, because papyrus was very expensive. Is this true? How much did papyrus really cost back then: how many square feet of papyrus was 1 horse, 1 slave, or 1 acre of arable land worth?

Q (previously posted) : Each of the 3 fragments has significant variation in character visibility. I wonder if this variation could have been caused primarily by the scribe dipping his pen in ink (when it has more ink, the pen presumably deposits thicker layers of ink). In general, how often did the scribes do it? Every how many characters?
I can confirm that they did not put spaces into their writing (screenshot of a piece of the *Hellenica*):
@Mae Sawatzky I know that they didn't use spaces. I'm asking if it's true that  papyrus cost was the reason.
:dcGiggle: I'm helping you believe.
Although the price is probably a major factor, yes. For both papyri and often the scribe's time as well. Not sure about the exact prices though.
@Mae Sawatzky Look at the spacing between the lines. If it was all about saving precious papyrus, they could have made those smaller.
The Hellenica is *massive*.  This one has 21 columns preserved, for a total of 72 fragments.
Romans didn’t use em either, they simply didn’t need it
https://papyri.info/dclp/59483
Imagine finding out that we have a full copy
Pure chaos :bearlaugh:
More so that the concept of spaces just didn't really exist
Inscriptions don't use spaces either
It's a fairly late scribal invention
Generally they weren't needed. If there was a distinction required, they used diacritics.
Spaces between lines though is probably for neatness.
Even very elaborate manuscripts do not use spaces
Thinking in particular of the Codex Argentus which is of course much later than the Herculaneum mss, but still in the Greco-Roman scribal tradition and employing a Greek-derived alphabet
Cf also modern Chinese which still does not use spaces
Maybe it signifies a different way of viewing language?

@JanPaul123 please tell us if you want this to be a q-only in preparation for May 25th or q&a as well. As for papyrus cost, i'm not convinced it was expensive either. This comes up on occasion, but it's probaby a shift of concept coming from parchment. Even if some receit was found that named the price in, say, Sesterca, the accual purchase value would still be hard to tell. Standard source would instead be the 'Edict of Diolecian on maximum prices', as it lists plenty of compare goods. And there is a section on Parchment and Papyrus, which is - lost. The Edict is itself an epigraphic puzzle, and this part has not been recovered.

Trivial papyri from the Oxyrichus collection seem to indicate that in Hellenistic Egypt at least, papyrus was cheap. They waste space, and note minor stuff. And in Rome, Papyrus was bulk import from Egypt, along with wheat.

Something I'm curious about is, the incredibly patient monks who unwrapped the scrolls by hand were able to read them directly. My samples are also very clear coming out of the oven. The ground truth samples needed to be imaged in infrared light though. Do we know what kind of mechanisms would cause the ink to degrade presumably with time since opening them? Just another thing I would like to try and simulate..
What's the distribution of letter sizes that we see across the collection?

Hi , I joined the challenge a few weeks ago and have a question for the experts. I was scanning through scroll 1 in the 6000-7250 region and found some punched holes and maybe the remnants of a seal.  I had the impression that maybe this is a legal document. This is more a question about access to papyri, than papyrology per se.  If I understand correctly, the data we are looking at comes from two scrolls, currently held in Paris, that were imaged in Oxford.  There also exists other scroll data, not part of the Vesuvius Challenge, from two scrolls held in Naples, that were imaged in Grenoble using X-ray phase contrast tomography.  The people who imaged the Naples scroll published a paper a few years ago, where they stated they had been able to read a few letters directly from the phase-contrast data, without the use of ML algorithms.  So my questions...

This is not part of the Vesuvius Challenge, since the data we have is the data we have.  But looking forward, what is the likelihood of reimaging the Paris scrolls using phase contrast methods?  Another question: any guesses as to the likelihood of the Naples group using the software developed as part of this challenge (which is open source, after all) to make another attempt at reading their data?  I am hoping (and of course everyone else is as well) that if the Vesuvius Challenge succeeds, both these efforts will gain momentum...

A summary of some takeaways regarding expected sheet and scroll structure:
- 2 orthogonal layers of fibers in a sheet.
- ~100um sheet thickness
- Scroll outer layer of a sheet = back of a sheet = vertical fibers.
- Scroll inner layer of a sheet = front of a sheet with writing = horizontal fibers.
- Sheet layers unlikely to delaminate with carbonization
- Carbonization likely fuses multiple sheets (big issue IMO)
- 10-20cm blank at start and end of scroll.
- 4.5-6cm columns, 1/6 of column space between columns
- ~1/8 height paddings top and bottom
I put your summary in the faq: https://scrollprize.org/faq#how-big-are-the-letters-and-where-can-we-expect-to-find-text

Just coming back to this after a few days. Hopefully you got your question answered, but if not... It's rarely the papyrological scholars who get to make these decisions (tho they can be great advocates) but rather the conservators and administrators in the libraries and museums. By their very nature, they are *conservative* with what is and is not allowed, and they will not allow experiment that poses likely or significant damage to the original object. Generally the bar is rather high now in terms of what will and will not be allowed, and sometimes the issue is as much the *perception* of risk as it is the actual risk. It's part of our job (the research scientists) to identify methods which minimize the risk and maximize the results, while also helping the conservators feel comfortable with the research plan and addressing their concerns about the methodologies. "Scanning a scroll" is often preceded by many months of legal, organizational, and scientific ground work.
Thanks for the follow up!

messages.content: What exactly makes the ink visible in IR? Is it simply a thicker layer of carbon, or is there something else (i.e. the gum arabic or similar used to make the ink) that scatters IR light better than scroll material?
Texture
So just the thickness of carbon layers where ink is present, then- not like iron gall ink where some chemical property of the ink matters

I believe the IR absorbance is due to a more intrinsic property of the ink, particularly related to the size and radiation responsiveness of the carbon particles. This can lead to an interestingly broad IR absorbance which, in turn, leads to a more black image against the relatively ordered cellulose background. Unfortunately this technique is not very penetrating so can't be used for depth scans of the scroll.

THZ wave imaging, between infrared and microwave, has the goldilocks properties of both being able to penetrate paper like organics and being influenced by ink chemistry. Give it five or ten years; they'll read the scrolls that way if this fails!
Here is a microscope image I took under both pure red and pure blue light: https://discord.com/channels/1079907749569237093/1079907750265499772/1106694411322134548

I've been thinking about ink detection and also wondering why IR gives such a (relatively) clear image and whether the particle accelerator can be configured to emulate (some of) the properties of IR somehow. I also wonder about angle of the beam and how that might impact readability similar to how changing the position of the light affects the readability of the words in the samples I just wrote up. The blue in the samples is interference blue. I don't have a conclusion but maybe this post will inspire some ideas about how to detect ink in ways we aren't currently using.

I also wanted to speculate on the crackling spots--maybe it's gum arabic? Inks, paints, etc were made with a pigment and a binder and it seems likely that the binder used was gum Arabic which is still commonly used today. Modern recipes for inks note that if you use too much gum arabic it can crack on the page a bit. It's basically crystalized sap so I could see how it might be redistributed in heat and then go back to crystalized form. Here's a pic of three kinds I have--powder, liquid, and rocks that formed from dried liquid (note that it was in my watercolor palette and is a bit contaminated with paint).
https://www.ceric-eric.eu/2021/04/01/press-release-coal-and-arabic-gum-in-ancient-roman-inks/

messages.content: I've been thinking about this for a while too. The absorption in IR is dependent on a regular size at the 1-2 micron scale.
From https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/sciadv.aav8936

The question is: knowing the frequency of this signal that contrasts so significantly from papyrus, how can it be extracted from x-ray imaging where the morphological data is quantized at 4, 8, or more microns?

I spent a little time trying to get chatGPT to come up with some ideas for me about what's going on and how we might apply that knowledge to solve the scrolls problem but the combination of my low level of physics knowledge and its lack of ability (from what I could see) to forge new understanding in novel ways meant that we didn't produce anything helpful (though I didn't spend a ton of time on it). It would be cool to have a better scienceGPT that might really be able to help us figure this out.
I'm not sure chatgpt is at a point where it can reason independently
The IR and CT images are fundamentally different in how they form images so it’s not really a matter of making one emulate the other.
IR forms images using reflectance and absorption, which is how we’re used to light interacting with visible objects
The CT is based on penetrance and filtered back projection, so the concept of ‘incidence angle’ has no meaning because it’s already being imaged at every available angle

Similarly, there’s not a way to change the frequency of the light either because you need a high energy beam that resists absorption and scattering and you REALLY don’t want to image with gamma rays if you can avoid it

I really appreciate the clarity of your explanation and agree that ionizing radiation is almost never the way to go.

What I'm trying to think about, though, is off-label configurations of the scanner that might give us a result that makes the next step in the process easier. Kind of like side channels in cryptography--rather than just brute forcing a result based on the available data you look for other signals that give clues and ultimately make the decoding process easier. Unfortunately I lack the optics knowledge for better brainstorm ideas.

If it were a simple thing presumably someone would've already tried it. It's hard to know what's impossible and what requires better imagination.

Everyone should keep doing what they're doing, which is frankly amazing and inspiring. But I hope that a few people have ideas brewing in the back of their minds about how to make things even better.

Ultimately, I think the image data is about as good as it’s going to get given the fact that we have to use a modality that doesn’t require contrast agents and produces volumetric data. Where the creativity has a lot of room to produce new paradigms is the interpretation of said data. Any day, someone could come up with the next ‘ink crackle hypothesis’ and change the way we look at the CT images moving forward

There's also x-ray fluorescence, phase contrast, and multiple energy scans. Lots more in CT besides standard attenuation imaging. But yeah, it's the tough trade off of needs to penetrate the part and needs to have variable absorption. If using a different technology, Long wavelength infrared (terahertz) is definitely going to be the next gen technique that works the best

If one were into python coding, one could separate out the low frequency visual components (the blobs, and the less visible grey areas over the parchment), throw away the high frequency components, and then map them to a colormap that is super sensitive near 0 (so any little perturbations show up).

A 2D image FFT should be perfect for this, as it should recover any blobby lower level letter signals, and then the colormapping allows us to use blatant changes in the color itself (easy to see) instead of tiny, tiny 1-5% changes in brightness.

I feel like that woul be the next step and would be incredibly useful in determining the more sus letters.

Re automated character recognition: I've been playing with Gen.jl and probabilistic programming by [implementing a paper](https://github.com/spelufo/gen_captcha/) that does captcha recognition. What is attractive about it is that you define the model that generates your data using plain code and then infer your latent variables, so you don't need tons of data to train on and it should generalize anyway since it "looks for" the best fit from your model's variables. My sense is that it is slow to converge so making inference fast enough can be challenging but they seem to have approaches to deal with that, such as using NNs as proposal solutions, and involutive MCMC. I'm not saying this would be better than NNs, probably not, I don't have a clue, but since I explored this I thought I'd mention it. messages.content: Another good resource is https://library.duke.edu/rubenstein/scriptorium/papyrus/ for images of papyri without accompanying transcription (sadly)

Hi all, I have been exploring language models for Greek and Latin (https://aclanthology.org/2023.acl-long.846/) and in my experience, there is no open-source resource as comprehensive as the TLG.

However, it also seems possible to access a current edition of the TLG if you ask Maria Pantelia nicely (see footnote 2: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2305.01099.pdf).

When training my language models, I combined several sources (First1KGreek, Greek Medieval Texts, Patrologia Graeca, Internet Archive texts).

There was some convo about training a trigram or quadragram guessing algorithm. This would be pretty straight forward to do with the right data processing. What we need are:
1. Photos of 3- or 4-grams, ideally cropped/zoomed so that the *letters are a consistent size* (note that's different from saying it's the same size image)
2. The string of known letters
3. (Optional but very helpful) a confidence score on a scale of 1 to 5

Nothing ! I work on proper images, I'm not playing with temporary data 😉 Papyrology is not a game, it is a real job (with years of practice and training).
Omg it's a real papyrologist tolerating us just like the channel description said!
Whoever wrote that was absolutely prescient lol
Exactly.
He's going to put all our translations on the fridge 🤣
Of course it's a real job! I wouldn't be having it if anyone claimed otherwise.
Why would I play with images that will be much improved in some days/weeks/months, when I just have to wait some more time.
"looky what I deciphered!" "That's nice dear"
We're *all* just very excited.
It's quite rare in our field, I'll admit!

and not only I'm a real papyrologist, but, as it is not mentioned on the website of the Vesuvius Challenge, I'm the one who brought the first fragments in Kentucky in 2008, for the very first experimentations that have failed. So I know very well these fragments and scrolls.
And that's why I'm so happy to see you here. 🙏
Ah, gotche
I love how certain small research discords can be a watering hole of people with extraordinarily unique cross discipline expertises
I haven't seen this many different fields in one, however
My field of expertise is making neural networks train uncommonly quickly, I hold one of the bigger benchmark records for it right now.
Papyrology was always a bit in advance in matter of technology. We even had a mail-list in the 90's (when 90% of hellenists had no clue about e-mails)
It's been fun (and a bit nerve wracking) to expand out a bit for me! 😅

I'll give some context, from my personal experience: As a palaeographer, I've been ridiculed by people from outside my field for years. So while it is super exciting to see so many people from so many disciplines coming together now, it also stings a tiny little bit. But I'm focusing 100% on the upside. And yes, us mere Hellenists are decades behind the papyrologists. They rock.
But hellenists always considered that papyrologists were working on garbage, when they were working on texts and books. Now, let's see how to upcycle garbage...
Well if it helps any I've held you in extremely high regard from the brief interactions we've had. I know basically nothing about anything hellenist vs papyrologist, so it's all Oromo to me.
Yeah this has a chance to be the finest garbage ever 🙂
Charlotte's web flashbacks

We love to fight for stupid considerations. That's the only thing you should know : at the end, we all are hellenists, but papyrologists work directly on papyri, unlike hellenists who study the final text (or medieval beautiful manuscripts)
Haha. I've never worked on a pretty manuscript.
Always the ugly, hard to read ones.
And for the last couple of years, on marginal notes.
So I feel you!

@fern 
Thank you! 😘

I consider myself a bridge maker. Yes, I'm a Hellenist but I've always collaborated with mathematicians, engineers, computer scientists, ... I'm now co-supervising a PhD in NLP and another one in computer sciences. I guess that's what I find so heart-warming in this channel: The mutual respect and the eagerness to truly collaborate across disciplines. It's the only way forward.
We need each other. Plus, it's a lot of fun.

@LaurentCP Maybe we can't really tell yet, but just to have a rough estimate, when would you say you and other papyrologists can start serious work on the data? Do you wait for more fragments for example, or for clearer images, or both? Not necessarily in terms of timing but I am curious about the future process.
How do you get transport these scrolls so far if they are extremely fragile to touch?
Fly them or train or truck?

The best quality I know of is on the first word announcement page on the website, there is also the color variation posted earlier in the thread but none with a ruler. Could be added in the google doc though!

I can't say precisely either, but the first thing to do is to wait and see the next improvement by the people who have tried to get images from these scrolls. So far, of course we see words, so what ? Words without any contest have no meaning. In the provided image, we don't have the upper lines or the lower ones. So yes, we have to wait for better images (which will arrive, I'm sure of that) and more images (if we are allowed to see them). I didn't see anytning in the Vesuvius Challenge mentioning the people who will get full access to the whole set of images at the end...

The fragments are all stuck on large leaves of silk paper. These leaves were put in a safe box that I was carrying always in the same position from Paris to Lexington, by train to Bruxelles, and then by plane to Cincinnati, where Brent Seales came to pick us.
Thanks a lot for the answer. I sure hope the future images will all be available, good point!
I'm guessing you said no when they asked if you could put it in the checked luggage 🙂

Let's say that the first experiments didn't bring the expected results (although we were really believing in them). But it's not a blame : research improves with a long chain of successes and failures, linked by hope...
I asked them not to put them through the X-ray machine, so they had to be put off the box, the box through the x-ray, and then back in the box. I was terrified !
Are you sure ?
We were young and beautiful 😅
Eventually the winning solutions will be made open source, so hopefully everyone will be able to see the full images.

"We will work with the Grand Prize winners to verify their results, put them in a historical context, and co-publish them in academic venues. The winning code will be made public under **a permissive open source license**, so that others can reproduce and build on your work."
Indeed, the question is will the 3D data of future scanned rolls also be available to reproduce the results on every scroll. But it would be great to make the final best images public.
Hopefully, indeed.
With the modern security CT machines, you should just say it's fine and then you don't have to go all the way to America

The scans we are working with are from 2019 (https://scrollprize.org/data_scrolls), I haven't seen the 90s images but I think it's safe to say that the new ones are better.
The MSI from the 90's were made on the open scrolls in Naples. Your scans are from the scrolls from Paris. There is no better or worse. It's not the same thing.
Okay
@JanPaul123 Hi Jan Paul! Out of curiosity,  is there already a plan for the availability of future images of the scrolls after the end of the challenge, independently of open source code?

I think it could be a hard thing as there's a bit of a PR balance too -- any early runner press narratives could get cemented quite quickly, and if this is one step in building a momentum ball for potential further excavation, at the very minimum having a closed data period during the initial analysis feels like it could potentially protect the project more than not.
It could also increase the focus on the eventual release of the findings and any future momentum building efforts as well, but I could be incorrect about this assertion.
Just my two cents as I'm curious about this too.
I wouldn't bet on large sections of the texts being released (freely) for the public anytime soon. which is why i am happy to have 'fun' with the picture we got
No concrete plan yet
Ok thanks!

My presence is not expert : my knowledge of Herculaneum papyri is.
See, that's just the kind of meticulous semantics we expect from an expert papyrologist

I know that some people find me fussy, but I do consider my job seriously and, indeed, papyrology is a meticulous discipline. Many misinterpretations of texts have been made by people who were not taking enough care of the material support of the text, or were not checking their readings on originals or good photographs. That's precisely the reason why I said earlier that I won't try to decipher few samples of this scroll now, when I have no doubt that better images will be obtained later by talented people (who, by the way, work very meticulously as well to interpret the data). I don't despise those who try, but if they want to learn papyrology, I invite them to follow the formation provided by many institutions all over the world.
I meant it as a high compliment!
As you say, programming itself is very detail-oriented work. One single wrong character and the rocket can explode.

I've been enjoying watching the crowd-sourced papyrology taking place in real time.  It's pretty exciting!
But I find the latest discussion to be a bit disappointing.  An expert papyrologist (a specialist in the Herculaneum papyri, no less!) shows up and offers a frank explanation of why he personally is not trying to decipher the current images.  The response is to accuse him (only slightly indirectly) of gatekeeping.
**People, this is not how you encourage experts in the field to show up here!**
Having been a specialist in one small area (not related to the humanities), I'm aware of how much expertise it sometimes takes to move a field forward.  Noting the need for deep expertise in a field is not gatekeeping.  
Of course, there may really be arbitrary gatekeeping going on in the field of papyrology (academics can be vicious!), but I would want to keep that discussion a bit separate from the current endeavor of deciphering the scrolls, in order not to discourage participation by recognized experts who might not want to devote their energy to making sure nothing that they say could be construed as gatekeeping.
I agree, let's get back to the scrolls 🙂 It's perfectly normal for experts to wait for proper, better data and in the meantime for others to have fun trying to make hypotheses with what we have.

I completely agree with theoldlove, we have many experts here in different fields, this much is true, although perhaps the... contribution of "experts in the field" has been a little lacklustre thus far? At any rate, we are all entitled to have our own fun with this data despite the rather disappointing nature of the quality of the images provided, these are interesting times indeed and I for one welcome as many Hellenists as we can muster to this cause, along with the expertise of those of course specialising in other fields which, one can hope, will provide us with the quality of image necessary for the "experts" to provide their own contribution, at their leisure, naturally.

I am grateful for the energy of the amateurs here who are having fun trying to interpret this new image, and I am also grateful for the patience and wisdom of the experts whose analyses we will all read with great interest when they are available. Everyone contributes in their own volitional manner and it's all great IMO!

Quite so, we wouldn't find ourselves in the situation we currently find ourselves without the work of an "amateur" student, not even a papyrologist no less! I think the amateur contribution has been rather fantastic and everyone here should be applauded for their efforts!

At the symposium recently, Brent Seales pointed out that they would like to use the scraps falling of the scroll all the time for C14-dating.
But what is the idea here?                                   What kind of insight would dating the material to about +-35 years of accuracy provide?

It can provide more information on whether the scrolls are contemporary to the eruption, or perhaps older, which can help in analyzing the the writing as to style and other factors, and it just provides another datapoint. Maybe it reveal something surprising, or maybe it confirms prior hypothesis.
I mean, we all know the scrolls were personally written by the Great Herculaneum of Vesuvius himself, right? ||/s 😭 😭 😭 😭 😭 😭 😭 😭 ||

It is a blurry data point though. Dating by writing style is often more accurate. I was wondering if there was a specific idea behind using a method that would probaly only mean anything if it found very old material.

One assumption that we papyrologists have been making is that the handwritings in the Herculaneum library are directly comparable with the ones known from Egypt and elsewhere, and so our dated parallels from Egypt can be straightforwardly used to date Herculaneum papyri. It would be nice to get some clarity on that question. I don't know about the calibration issues or if C14 dating would provide narrow enough results (say, a fifty year range) to be useful. With literary texts on papyrus, I think it's fair to say that we're usually content with a range of a century for dating by handwriting, half a century if we're lucky.

Ok, i see. This assumes ofcourse that the papyrus was only about as old as the writing now on it, but that is probaly fair to assume. As for calibration, there is C14-depletet carbon everywhere near the Vulcano. Vulcanified wood from nearby has been calibrated to dentrochronology by Karl-Uwe Häussner, but i don't know how well that translates to papyrus.
Yeah, we wouldn't normally expect papyrus to be more than a few years older than its first use. All you need is some time for manufacture, shipping, and retail, then just storage until use.

There are discussion of the stichometry of particular rolls in their individual editions

Usually, but not always, a stichos is a line the length of a dacytlic hexameter (the meter of Homer), and prose was written in shorter lines, so you have to multiply the stichos total by 1.8 or 2 to get the actual line count
(it always works that way in Herculaneum so far as I know)

```
ἐ̣π̣ὶ τῶν βρω̣μ̣άτ̣ων | ο̣ὐ̣κ ἤδ̣η τὰ ϲπάνια | πάντωϲ̣ καὶ ἡδ̣ίω | τῶν δ̣αψιλῶν̣ ε̣ἶναι̣ | νομίζ̣ο̣με̣ν·
```
The word translated as *we believe* is [νομίζομεν](https://logeion.uchicago.edu/%CE%BD%CE%BF%CE%BC%CE%AF%CE%B6%CF%89). Νομίζω does also occur in the NT. I understand no form of πιστεύω appears in the public transcriptions.

πιστεύω is used in NT, for instance in Mark 1.15: μετανοεῖτε καὶ πιστεύετε ἐν τῷ εὐαγγελίῳ: repent ye, and believe the gospel (KJV). The text(s) on which modern editions of the Old Testament are based are the jewish texts, written in Hebrew and Aramaic. They of course don’t use the Greek πιστεύω. (The Septuagint does use it for instance in what is now psalm 78.22 “because they believed not in God”.) Πιστεύω has a different meaning from νομίζω, which means “to believe, think, be of the opinion”. For instance the Nicene creed opens πιστεύω εἰς ἕνα Θεόν, I believe in one God etc. However, it is a fairly standard Greek word, used by Thucydides and Aeschylus amongst others.

Alternative translations are always welcome, but yes, it would be nice to have access to the prize awarding discussions.

It would be interesting to see a transcription effort in the open, collaborating through a github repo. Transcriptions are just text, after all, and version control would help, I think. I know papyrologists may not have experience with git, but editing the transcriptions and proposing changes can all be done through the github website. I can help set up a repo if I get a green light, I almost did at one point, but I hesitated because of the potential copyright issues.

To add, I can understand why professional papyrologists don't necessarily want their WIP readings made public. Even if they have those passages of readable text, small uncertainties can lead to large differences in interpretation, and the issues that stem from erroneous public transcriptions/translations could take some time to correct and prove to be a pain academically.

This is compounded because papyrologists are used to working in a field of niche interest, for an expert audience, in an environment where people are generally working towards printed books, not transcriptions that can be quickly corrected online. 

 Though the papyrologists I know make early transcriptions of new manuscripts pretty quickly, they then spend years on the secondary research, analysing the context and meta-features of the text, trying to scratch out a few more very difficult letters, which often makes a huge difference to their work on interpretation. By far the most significant and lengthiest part of papyrological work is in this stuff --- banging out a preliminary transcription is just a first step. 

For the audience papyrologists usually publish for, a few more lines of random Philodemus without this research may not be of enough interest to make public, especially when it seems that much more text --- and better images of the current text --- is coming reasonably soon. I think if anything sensational turns up it will be published fairly quickly, and there will be more text revealed alongside further technical advances. There could be talks with bits and pieces. But, when it comes to a general 'edition' of this or any of the other texts, it could take a long time... it could well be years away. The papyrologists I know would take several years to publish a text of the currently revealed length, *letalone a whole scroll (though they don't work with a completely known language, so the situation is somewhat different).

And yeah, though more text would be fantastic, I enjoy grappling with these early readings anyway, even if it is ultimately redundant (though I very much would love to have a papyrologist to hit me with a figurative giant book on the head whenever I do anything foolish 😅 , it really isn't right to do papyrology without this).

Anyway, there is a lot more interest in digital humanities in Classics in general, and I think the Vesuvius Challenge will end up advancing things significantly in the end.
If the github repo was publicly available it would contravene the data agreement, alas.

Final thought: beyond the GP passages, managing regular releases/updates of state of the art transcriptions/translations would be a hell of a lot of work, and I imagine there aren't currently enough *professionals around to do it regardless (especially given the masses of papyrology now in the pipeline).

messages.content:
Just for fun I asked Claude 3 (Opus model) to try to decipher an image of ink-labels I took from the repository created by @polytrope . As a first attempt it seems a pretty modest effort to me. But I thought you might be interested in seeing the result. I used the Claude "workbench" prompting Claude to act as a papyrologist experienced at deciphering 1st Cent Greek texts.
---- Claude's response ---- 
"This appears to be a very challenging papyrus fragment to decipher, as the ink has faded significantly and there are many gaps and damaged areas in the text. I'll do my best to make out some possible words and phrases, but my confidence level will be quite low given the poor state of preservation.
In the first line, I believe I see the letters ΚΡΙΝΗΡ, which could potentially be a form of the verb κρίνω meaning "to judge/decide".
In the second line, the sequence ΤΩΝΟ looks like it could be the genitive plural form of the definite article ὁ, ἡ, τό.
A few lines down, I see ΤΟΙΣ followed by ΤΗΝ which may be the sequence τοῖς τὴν, using the dative plural masculine and accusative singular feminine forms of the definite article.
Near the bottom, the letters ΤΩΝΠΡΟϹΘ are faintly visible, which could represent τῶν πρόσθε meaning "of those before/in front".
And at the very end, I believe I make out ΤΟΥΤΙΡΟϹΘΟΛΙϹΘΗΝΑΙ, but I'm not at all certain of the letters. If correct, it could conceivably be a form of the verb ὀλισθάνω meaning "to slip/fall".
Again, these are highly tentative guesses based on the few letters I can make out. The vast majority of the text is too damaged or faded for me to decipher with any real confidence. We would need higher resolution, multispectral imaging and more advanced techniques to have a better chance of reconstructing the contents. But those are my initial impressions of this challenging fragment. Let me know if you would like me to take a closer look at any particular section."
--- ends---

It is not just 1st century Greek text. Some texts are close to the eruption, some are 100-200 years old and were apparently brought over from Greece. Maybe just keep it more general "Greek-language texts from Antiquity".

And I would not ask him to ask like a papyrologists because they need to be extremely cautious and only proclaim discoveries that they are confident about but any wrong word leaking out leads to confusion. 😉  So maybe ask "Give us your best guess for each word and describe the topic of the text."

Good points. Tom. Although I wonder if there would be much difference between 1st C. CE text and 200 BCE text. AFAIK the orthographic traditions of Greek did not change much between the 4th century and the Byzantine period hundreds of years later.

I'm not sure whether Claude.ai can be of much help. But it might be possible for someone knowledgeable about papyrology to use the API interface to get much better results. I consider Claude is by far the best of the current LLMs in Greek and Latin languages: I believe it has been trained on large amounts of (modern editions of) classical text. It also has excellent image recognition and image-query capabilities. So I would not be surprised if it has *some* potential uses in this project.

In my opinion:

(1) An LLM can just help a papyrologist to start out with an initial guess or give inspiration when you are stuck. A bit like I use Wiki.

(2) Before using Claude.ai or others, the project needs a collaboration tool, a web interface  where the best ink images are displayed on the left and a user can enter a best guess on the right. And then the user community rates other users' guesses.

(3) If we don't do this, we get lost because the amount of words to be read is enormous if it all works out as planned. 15 columns is 5%, so the whole scroll has 20*15 =300 columns. Times 300 scrolls, gives us 90'000 columns! 20 lines per column and we get 1'800'000 lines! And 4 words per line, so 7 million words. lets be conservative: at least 1 million words!

(4) Once this web interface is in place, the user could be fed with LLM suggestions for words and then click OK or wrong or unclear. And I guess as more words are identified, an AI could be trained to become better.

(a) Instead of using an image, can you not take @polytrope 's work on the 16 columns from above and then ask Claude.ai to check it and correct mistakes and fill in the gaps? And then send this to her for feedback.

(b) apparently papyrologists can determine the time period of a papyrus by the style and wording used. I read this somewhere.

Hmm... Yes, I guess so. But I'm not sufficiently expert in Greek to know whether any criticisms or suggestions from Claude.ai would be well-founded or useful. If @polytrope thought it might be helpful (and were unable to do this for herself), I'd be happy to help, but I'm reluctant to start offering a critique whose quality I cannot vouch for. That sort of thing just derails real progress, don't you think?

Obligatory not a papyrologist, but I am professional software engineer focusing in ML for which I've done a lot of training and inference, as well as compilers for ML/AI networks themselves.

TL;DR: feeding labels, or any explicit vesuvius challenge data to any public LLM, is naively reckless at best and actively harmful at worse. 

I don't remember the ins and outs of the data privacy agreement we all signed to get the data, but it explicitly prohibits sharing, and I assume that includes all derivative works, which includes ink labels. No one knows how any public LLM company will handle the data. They might _say_ it's private and/or not used for training, but they all lie. Giving out the data in this way could negatively affect our access to the data, or even the entire vesuvius challenge as a whole, as the institutions that own the data may see it as people expressly disobeying the privacy rules.

Then there's how LLMs work. LLMs have no concept of truth, lies, facts, etc. You can train them to regurgitate facts, but the only way that we can currently know if LLM output is truthful is human fact checking and interaction. If you or another human are unable to verify output, then you have no basis of trust. AI generated content  waters down human communication as a whole and adds more noise and less signal to what we're trying to achieve here.

I'm not trying to be critical of the _idea_ of using LLMs and AI and such, obviously AI has huge benefits in this challenge; it helped enable the grand prize last year. I use Claude quite a lot for coding and have used it to help with with mesh visualization, code cleanup, and a lot of related tasks, and it is incredibly powerful. But I have professional experience with ML so I know its limitations, I can immediately verify the code it gives me back, and I'm not feeding it and vesuvius challenge exclusive data. I wouldn't ask it to try reading greek. Or even Old Norse, which I actually have some command of

I think there _is_ a benefit to having a vesuvius trained LLM for the purposes of the project that accessible only to participants, but I am skeptical of it creating more signal than noise, or what it could do vs couldn't, or what it _should_ do or shouldn't. For example, if it's training on this discord history, how do we verify we only train it on facts? There has been a lot of speculation in this discord - which is totally cool - but the process of data cleaning and verification would be huge. We could have papyrologists and historians look at everything, but they have better things to do.

Then, if we start including LLM generated data in this discord, we pollute what has been written by actual people, making any further training harder and harder as we feed accidentally, or on purpose, feed LLM output into an LLM. I am not on this discord to read what ChatGPT regurgitated, I am here to read what real people wrote.
Very well said. I also don't really think these public LLMs have a chance of competing with the experts in these domains in any meaningful way.

As far as I am concerned, they have no chance. We _don't know_ what these LLMs are trained on. We _don't know_ how LLMs generate the output they do. We don't have the bandwidth to feed all of the potential output to people that can actually do the verification. That right there is grounds for distrust. 

We _can_ trust some models, like the grand prize models, because we know the entire domain of the training data, we can generalize them to unseen data, and we had a ton of real professionals do a ton of work to verify everything. If you don't have all that, then you can't have confidence in any ML model that's operating on problems with stakes this high.

Although I'm optimistic about machine learning helping with  the reading of the Herculaneum papyri eventually, I agree that it is unlikely to be of much use at this point, without training on huge datasets particular to --- or at least similar to --- these scrolls.

There is a really interesting project called *Ithaca* that has been developed to fill in lacunae --- areas of missing text --- in ancient Greek inscriptions: https://ithaca.deepmind.com/. I can imagine something similar being eventually developed for the Herculaneum papyri. Ithaca fills in gaps in identified text only, rather than parsing images of the text, which would be a more difficult proposition altogether.

As for your counsel against asking an LLM to "try reading greek": maybe you should try it before "professionally" dismissing the idea. Before even talking about using machine learning, we need to set up a framework where ML can be used in a productive way.

And within this framework, we can add quantitative tools, e.g. a list of letters from which a user can choose from, a list of words that fit the so-far-found letters, and only then more sophisticated ML tools ( where we can have a serious discussion about how to use them.)

Hi, I have a reading and translation of Column -1 (the last column), which differs somewhat from the version on the scrollprize website (https://scrollprize.org/grandprize) that I’d like some help on. It perhaps also illustrates some of the difficulties when transcribing/translating the scrolls.
In line 1, I read π̣αρα[τ̣]ρ̣έχο̣ν̣τ̣α̣ϲ̣ instead of γὰρ ἀπ̣εχόμ̣ε̣θ̣α̣  —  the scrollprize website is missing the γ, but a slide presentation I viewed earlier included it.

To avoid a text wall, I’ve attached some screenshots of an informal discussion of it, but I also have some questions!

1. The official version translates κρίνειν as ‘question’ (I’ve rendered it ‘pass judgement on’). In the Cambridge Greek lexicon, ‘question’ is given as the last of 22 definitions of κρίνειν, for which there is only one citation (Sophocles), where it applies to questioning a person, not ‘matters’ ---  a very different context! Does anyone know of any places where it is used with the definition ‘question’ elsewhere (especially Philodemus)?

2. ἐμφαίνω seems to be used impersonally here in a way similar to δῆλόν ἐστιν -> does anyone have any parallels for this?

3.  I’ve rendered ὥϲπερ πολλά̣κιϲ ἂν as ‘just as often as’. ὥσπερ ἄν = ἕως ἄν, so long as, or however long, in the dictionary, but it is a rare definition, and I’m not sure if πολλάκιϲ can appear between the two components. Does anyone have a good parallel for this? messages.content: I always forget that the letters are hand written with so many variations

One big difference between modern and ancient times is the lack of (global) standards in Antiquity. Our world has literally millions of standards such as the metric system., ISO norms, internal norms. They didn't, and at best they had local standards, for example at the market square there was a standard length and weight and all other lengths and weights were calibrated to this one standard. So one standard per town. Products were also not standardized unless they came from the same factory or workshop. Of course the Roman empire, in particular, had the power to impose standards but in pre-industrial times it was cumbersome and limited.

I do genealogy and trying to read 18th century handwriting is much worse than the Greek writing on the Herculaneum scrolls as the letters merge into each other and parish books are not academic texts where the author writes neatly with the reader in mind. On the other hand, Middle Age bibles are easy to read, once you get used to the letters, because it is one letter at a time, standardized, and by professional scribes.

I feel like the ε-shape is probably just following the lines in the papyrus, or horizontal and vertical cracks that follow the papyrus reeds.

The other two, depends on size, position in the line, etc.

The issue with the κατα that Delattre mentions has been resolved in the latest series of images produced by a model trained on my updated ink labels (see attached image). The top of what looks like the 'ϲ' in the first image is probably the left hand side of the horizontal of the τ intersecting with the α. This has a 'curled' shape. The round base of the 'ϲ' could be interference, or a very long bottom leg on the κ produced by a trailing pen. The issue is more missing data than hallucination.

For the μ in θαυμάϲιον, the line being detected appears in a slightly different set of 'layers' to the rest of the word. It might be ink 'bleeding' through from another sheet (it does look like regular crackle, not a crease in the papyrus).
You might want to post this in the comment section of the YouTube video?
It's Koine Greek

I have a question on how you updated the labels. Did you

(a) look harder at the pictures of each layer to detect evidence of ink?

(b) just play around (randomly and playful) with labelling and found overall crisper letters?

(c) guess the letters κ . τ α and based on this update the labels?

(d) guess the word κατα and based on this update the labels for the first α

And a question on Greek itself: what is the difference between α and ά? is the inflection on the α to show that the word is most pronounced on this α and not the other α?

Yes to a, c, and d. The other thing is knowing the likely shape of the characters themselves --- for example, you might notice in the image above that the α's usually have a right leg that end higher up than the left leg, or the top of the υ tends to curl down on the left-hand side and up on right-hand side. Noticing these details, it's easier to fill in the 'gaps' in particular characters --- and I have definitely become better at that over time. 

The ά (acute), ὰ (grave), ᾶ (circumflex) accents, in Koine Greek, do all end up just indicating where the stress is in a word: so kaTA not KAta. 

The reason that there are 3 is that they were invented in the 3rd century BCE  to show the older/Homeric pitch accent (so, the ά would probably indicate a high tone on a short vowel and a rising tone on a long vowel, etc). The diacritics are the kind of thing that are invented when the accent is in the process of being lost (they weren't generally written in Philodemus' time, though, and aren't in this manuscript).

There's some debate over when the pitch accent completely died out (some distinctions disappeared before others), but it was well on its way, if not generally gone, by Philodemus' time. Philodemus, being posh, is more likely to have used some reduced form of the pitch accent.

The other important mark is the rough (ἥ) and smooth (ἤ) breathing, the ’‘ above vowels and ρ at the beginning of a word, to show whether there is a 'h' or not.

So ἡ is pronouced /heː/ (one of the words for 'the') and ἤ /eː/ ('or'). The rough/smooth breathing isn't written in these manuscripts either, so you can imagine it can be a pain telling what η is doing in a fragmentary manuscript (especially as it is a common letter anyway!). The /h/ sound at the beginning of words also died out during the Koine period, but as pronouncing it was probably a status marker, Philodemus probably said it.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek_accent

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_diacritics

Thanks! So it is similar to German Sonderzeichen (ü,ö,ä) and the French accents (é,è,à). 

"so you can imagine it can be a pain telling what η is doing in a fragmentary manuscript (especially as it is a common letter anyway!)."

I would guess that it might be a pain to know which form of the letter (i.e α, ά, ὰ or ᾶ) it is but the meaning should still be clear?

I speak fluently German and French, and if I were to drop all the accents on the letters. I think I could still read all words unambiguously. It is mostly a help on how to pronounce.

Ok, in French, an issue might arise because ou (=or) and  où (=where) could change the meaning of the sentence (the pronunciation is strangely enough the same) but if I have all the words in the sentence it should still be clear which one. Of course, if some letters or words in a sentence are missing then it might be crucial to know with or without or what accent in order to understand the meaning of the sentence.

I reckon I would have to think for some time to answer that properly. I'd say between 3 and 4, only certain letters that can possibly come next to each other, even below the word level. E.g. if you read ζδγ in a row, something must be wrong. There are a limited number of sequences that can begin words, end words, etc.

More than possibility, it's also likelihood...some combinations of letters and words are much more likely than others, esp. in context (e.g. the author repeating the same word).

Another issue, as Delattre mentions, is that sentences in this text are long (often 12 lines), and there aren't many complete sentences at all. Greek has a much more free sentence order than English -- the main verb can be left to the end of the sentence, adjectives can be somewhat apart from the nouns they agree with, and, if you've referred to something already, it's generally good style not to repeat the full word (so imagine a phrase like 'the [thing] in the desert', which should be 'the house in the desert', but house is omitted because it is mentioned in the previous sentence). 

It makes it harder to understand what is going on clearly if you only have half a sentence.

I just read through the following article from 2003 that describes an earlier attempt to decipher the H. scrolls by BYU. From the article, it seems like they tried to physically unroll some of the scrolls and then used multispectral imaging to decipher the texts on some (many?) of the resulting fragments. Does anyone know a) if they had much success? b) where to find the images they produced?. Reading between the lines, my assumption is that they had some success reading the fragments but may have damaged some of the scrolls and gave up at some point - hence the need for the virtual unwrapping we are doing these days. But would love to know the back story if anyone knows this? They do make grand claims about the potential for breakthroughs using multispectral imaging, but it seemingly did not result in the breakthroughts they were hoping for. Here is the bibliographical info for that article: Chabries, Douglas M, Steven W Booras & Gregory H Bearman. 2003. “Imaging the past: recent applications of multispectral imaging technology to deciphering manuscripts”. Antiquity 77 (296): 359-372 (and the link to where it's hosted on CUP online, if you have access: https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/antiquity/article/abs/imaging-the-past-recent-applications-of-multispectral-imaging-technology-to-deciphering-manuscripts/E6C39142EEA0C5C66A1E644D0D99873A)
Unfortunately I do not have the credentials to read the document

I am sure I cannot simply provide the article as a PDF for copyright reasons, but Fair Use certainly allows for a short excerpt - and the section on the H. scrolls is just a small part of it (4 pages), so I think I can share that (if someone with more copyright knowledge than I thinks this to be mistaken, please let me know and I will delete the excerpt). So here you go:

People have tried to unroll scrolls for 2 centuries with varying success but always with permanent damage to the scrolls and huge loss in texts. BUT they did read quite a bit of the open fragments they got. The topic and author of many unrolled books are now known but very few with complete text passages over several columns.

These multispectral methods have only enabled to read more text from these fragments than the naked eye (with the help of a microscope at times) can detect in visible light.

The method of the Vesuvius challenge is different in that it is non-invasive, but it is very hard as carbonized scrolls are messy objects and ink and papyrus give the same response in scans forcing us  to search for difference in texture between them


Read the book by David Sider THE LIBRARY OF THE VILLA DEI PAPIRI for the status before the V challenge.

the general letters have been the same for a wide range of different models/from multiple groups for last year's Grand Prize challenge. You can check out some of the different predictions of different models here: https://scrollprize.org/grandprize#runners-up
The results of all the groups are very similar character wise. Some detect more ink, some less, some with more or less clarity in different regions and so on. Each model has it's own "fingerprint" (for example a greyish papyrus tone, or whiter ink traces, ...).

generally it seems, that every scroll that we scanned so far has a different personality. and you are right, reading one scroll and generalizing to the next has its challenges. from looking at the fragments, we can estimate that reading the first 2-4 scrolls will be the hardest until the ink detection models learn to generalize to new and unseen scrolls better.

...actually, having listened to the next 10 seconds of the talk, I've realised it's because she was reading off the big combined image that was manually cropped together, rather than the individual segments. 

In the combined image, this column was imprecisely glued to the adjoining column, accounting for the duplication (answering my own question!). The error isn't present in the original GP image, either.
This is a huge part of why I think papyrologists will have to become familiar with this whole process

I don’t see how it will be possible to make reliable interpretations without having at least a working knowledge of how the entire process works , not necessarily how to do it but what goes into making it

She was able to figure this out given that papyrologists are well used to working with fragmented and mangled texts , and she’s obviously very good at her job, but this kind of thing would probably come quicker in the future with this knowledge

I imagine a fully integrated pipeline at the end, where after the location of characters has been detected, users/papyrologists could refine the whole process from segmentation to detection with different models on a single character level and get outputs at near real time to crowdsource the refinement bits that might not be reachable via automatic means. I wonder how people see this? I could imagine that ML people would rather go for a complete automatic pipeline while papyrologists would go for as much control and insight over the whole process as possible?

Personally I'm a big believer in human in the loop, where you supply as good as possible automatic tooling, but used in a pipeline where at any step someone can intervene. Ideally with realtime feedback. If you produce enough supervision with such pipeline eventually you can mostly automate it, but without data ML is kinda tricky. I want to push VC in this direction.

I see it similar.
Speeding up the whole process and going from ash to text as quickly as possible is crucial to get an economically viable approach to reading the scrolls.
Letting computers do the hard work and having a human that can go and adjust each piece along the way and verify quickly if the machine did a god job is important.
That applies to CT scan reconstruction, segmentation, ink detection and also in the future maybe Optical Character Recognition, Machine Transcription, Machine Translation into modern languages and analysis of the text as well.
We could even add on automatic audiobook generation to get that 21st century feeling 🙂
Basically dig up the scroll, press a button and get an audiobook? Would be my dream!

There's the question of how to divide the labor between humans and machines (as @RICHI pointed out, you need scroll-to-text automation in order to scale), but there is also a division between centralized and decentralized.  The initial automated segmentation and ink detection will necessarily be done at a central facility, with technical staff running the computers, and perhaps some papyrologists to help with quality control.
But for many years to come, long after the "scroll factory" has finished working, scholars will want to conduct detailed study of individual scrolls.
In this case, I imagine that the papyrologists will want to run the software themselves.  Examining (and improving) the segmentation is especially important, to ensure that characters aren't bleeding through from  a different layer.
So there should be some thought given, not just to developing user-friendly software for editing segments (this is already being done by a few of us, I think!), but also how to deploy the software (including training) to the end users, who I assume will be for the most part papyrologists rather than technical specialists.

Regarding centralized vs. decentralized, there's a whole spectrum of how things could be done. It could be fully decentralized with different teams using different variants of data sets and software, to a canonical dataset and (e.g. web) application centrally deployed while still making the data itself available in various formats. If you take Wikipedia or OpenStreetMap as an example, they have a centralized infrastructure to share and maintain the canonical data set but by sharing the datasets they allow all kinds of downstream applications.

That's a good way of putting it.  The centralized team would generate canonical results (segmentation, virtual unwrapping/ink detection, and OCRed text), for all the scrolls.  They really would do this for all the scrolls, not just a subset, since their mission is "read all the scrolls", and they would not delegate this work to other groups, since they would want the results to be consistent across all the scrolls.
Then they would make these canonical results available for anyone who is interested in doing more detailed studies.  Hopefully those people would in turn make their improved results (segmentation etc) available for others to improve in turn.  Ideally, the centralized team would, as you suggested, create a platform for sharing these improvements.

Super delayed response to all this: I think everything that can be automated should be automated --- there are too few scholars, and too much text. Only 5000ish of the 400,000+ Oxyrhynchus papyri have been published in the 125 years since they have been discovered, for instance. Automated text recognition/transcription, even rudimentary, could be incredible... it could at least help categorise different kinds of documents.

Imagine a scholar researching 2nd Century CE grain contracts, for example... imagine if everything were digitised in an open database: handwriting recognition could help isolate the texts written in the 2nd Century, and text recognition of different formulae etc could allow the researcher to more readily find those contracts. It could also hopefully help piece different fragmentary texts together.

Not everything will be able to be automated: for example, the undeciphered Greek papyrus I studied at a papyrology workshop contained a hapax legomenon --- a word that had never been found anywhere else before --- so there was no way to look that up exactly in a dictionary. This is not that uncommon.

However, I'm sure papyrologists in the future will be using a very *different methodology than they are today --- they will want fine grained control to check everything, for sure, and many tools will become indispensable. I think that there are many aspects of the process even now, though, that papyrology expertise could help with, too.

For those making ink labels, for example, understanding the stroke order and shape of the characters really helps --- it helps the annotator make educated guesses (should the leg of the π be straight or curled? Does the stroke have a foot or not?). In a lot of cases when I've been making ink labels, I've been aware that If I had more experience or could ask specific questions, I could do a significantly better job.

Here's an example of some of the variance of the hands we have seen, so far, for instance. Descriptions are not formal papyrological descriptions, though.
